3.1 Sample space and Event Let \(\Omega\) (the sample space of all possible outcomes of an experiments) be an arbitrary non-empty set. Its elements, denoted by \(\omega\), will be interpreted as outcomes (results) of some experiment. These outcomes sometimes called simple events or elements becaus they cannot be decomposed further. Other events (subsets of \(\Omega\)) are compound events because they are composed of two or more simple events. An event \(A\) occurs if and only if the randomly selected \(\omega\) belongs to \(A\). As usual, we use \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cap B\) to represent the union and the intersection of any two subsets \(A\) and \(B\) of \(\Omega\), respectively. Also, \(A^c\) is the complement of \(A\subset \Omega\). In particular, \(\Omega^c=\theta\), where \(\theta\) is the empty set. Example 2.1 (an example of sample space and event) When drawing randomly from \([0,1]\) the sample space is \(\Omega = [0,1]\), each \(\omega \in [0,1]\) is a sample event, and the interval \(A=(\frac{1}{2},1]\) is an example of a compound event.

3.3 Sigma-fields in real line We next consider \(\sigma\)-fields when \(\Omega\) is the uncountable set \(\mathbb{R}\) (or an interval). Again, any useful \(\sigma\)-field must contain each singleton \(\omega\). Definition 2.6 (Co-finite and co-countable) The set \(A\in\Omega\) is called co-finite set if its complement \(A^C\) is finnite. Further, the set \(A\in\Omega\) is called a co-countable set if \(A^C\) is countable. Let \(\mathcal{F}_{1}\) consist of the finite and co-finite subsets of \(\Omega\). Then, \(\mathcal{F}_{1}\) is a field. It is a \(\sigma\)-field if and only if \(\Omega\) is finite. Let \(\mathcal{F}_{2}\) consist of the countable and the co-countable subsets of \(\Omega\). Then it is easy to check that \(\mathcal{F}_{2}\) is a \(\sigma\)-field. Exercise 2.1 Prove that the collection of countable and co-countable sets is itself a \(\sigma\)-field. Example 2.9 (A sigma-field of subsets of sample space need not contain all subsets of sample space) Suppose that \(\Omega\) is uncountable. Then \(\Omega\) contains a subset \(A\) such that \(A\) and \(A^C\) are both uncountable. This show that in general a \(\sigma\)-field of \(\Omega\) need not contain all subsets of \(\Omega\) and need not be closed under the formation of arbitrary uncountable unions. Example 2.10 (Sigma-field of countable and co-countable sets: too small) Suppose that \(\Omega\) is uncountable set like \(\mathbb{R}\) or \([0,1]\). If we want \(\mathcal{F}\) to include each singleton \(\omega\), then \(\mathcal{F}\) must contain each countable subset \(A\). It must also contain the complement of each countable set. Therefore, any \(\sigma\)-field containing the singletons must contain all countable and co-countable sets. Unfortunately, this \(\sigma\)-field is not large enough to be useful. For instance, if \(\Omeag=[0,1]\), then we are not allowed to consider events like \([0,\frac{1}{2}]\) because it is neither countable nor co-countable.
